awd_titl_txt: Arithmetic Manifolds, Automorphic Forms, Exponential Sums, and L-Functions
awd_abstract_narration:
This project features two lines of research at the interface of mathematical analysis, the study of continuous change, and number theory, the study of properties of integers borne out of the notion of divisibility. The finer distribution of prime numbers, such as whether they end in certain blocks of digits more often than others, is captured by highly structured oscillating sequences known as Dirichlet characters, which give rise to the associated L-functions. This project will prove analytic results about certain special values of L-functions and sums of the values of Dirichlet characters, and it will specifically investigate the impact of the underlying modulus being composed of many smaller factors on these results and on the tools available to prove them. As a prototype of the other class of objects to be studied, signals and motions (such as light waves or vibrations of a string) are often much better understood when viewed as combinations, or superpositions, of simple periodic motions. The wave-like functions that analogously serve as building blocks of analysis on other spaces are known as eigenfunctions and are central in disciplines ranging from spectral geometry to quantum mechanics. This project will investigate the behavior of rapidly oscillating eigenfunctions on spaces with a rich set of symmetries that are arithmetic in nature, in particular how pronounced are their extreme values.

This research project centers around two principal themes, that of extremal behavior of high-energy eigenfunctions on arithmetic manifolds and that of the depth and smooth aspects in analytic number theory. On certain arithmetic manifolds with a specific geometric and functorial structure, the joint eigenfunctions (Hecke--Maass eigenforms) exhibit power growth, which is neither generically expected nor predicted by physical models. The PI will seek out extremal growth and investigate in detail the sup-norm and restriction norm problems on several specific classes of arithmetic manifolds to inform general conjectures and understanding of the phenomenon of concentration of mass on arithmetic manifolds, the precise structure that drives it, and its place within the framework of the correspondence principle of quantum mechanics. In number-theoretic problems involving characters and automorphic forms of large level, the depth and smooth aspects, which are concerned with highly powerful or factorable conductors, play a very distinctive role. The structural impact of the powerful or factorable structure on nonvanishing, subconvexity, and moments of L-functions, as well as exponential sums involving p-adically analytic fluctuations will be studied using non-archimedean analysis, analytic number theory, and spectral theory.

por.por_cntn:
This project at the interface of mathematical analysis and number theory proved results on automorphic forms and L-functions.

Eigenforms are analogs of purely periodic motions which serve as building blocks of analysis on curved spaces (manifolds) such as spheres or donut-shaped surfaces and their higher-dimensional analogs. Arithmetic manifolds are an important subclass, with often markedly non-generic spectral properties. In joint work with Blomer, Harcos, and Maga, the PI proved new strong subconvex upper bounds for Hecke-Maass eigenforms over arbitrary number fields, improving simultaneously in the spectral and level aspects. This work shows that, on a broad class of arithmetic spaces, the mass of eigenforms concentrates much less than is generically allowed. This meshes well with the chaoticity of movement patterns and supports outstanding conjectured principles of quantum mechanics.

L-functions are analytic objects that can be associated to many arithmetic or geometric objects, for example to "elliptic curves", which can quite literally be seen as certain planar curves with a rich arithmetic structure. Moments of L-functions provide statistical information about their values such as the average or the standard deviation, which in turn yields conclusions about the vanishing of some of these L-functions, or about the underlying arithmetic structure. In joint work with Blomer, Fouvry, Kowalski, Michel, and Sawin, the PI developed asymptotic formulas (with power savings) and the full analytic theory of the second moment of central values in the family of twists of a fixed GL(2) form with all Dirichlet characters modulo a large prime, including (as the Eisenstein case) the fourth moment of Dirichlet L-functions. This work provides a strong version of the second moment evaluation in the family of L-functions obtained from a fixed L-function by a natural variation and its rich arithmetic consequences for nonvanishing, analytic rank, and extreme values.

Dirichlet L-functions encode essential information about distribution of prime numbers in a form amenable to analysis. In joint work with Khan and Ngo, the PI proved that a positive proportion (at least 1/3) of Dirichlet L-functions to a high prime power modulus do not vanish already within an arbitrary Galois orbits of primitive Dirichlet characters. In joint work with White, the PI obtained an upper bound for the twelfth moment of Dirichlet L-functions to a high prime power modulus analogous to Heath-Brown's estimate for the Riemann zeta function. It is generally conjectured that the central values of Dirichlet L-functions should not be too large (Lindelof hypothesis) but also that they should not vanish. The obtained results confirm nonvanishing for a large proportion of L-functions even when considered within rather small naturally occurring clusters, and prove upper bounds showing that not too many central L-values in this family can be too large.

Automorphic forms naturally occur in families. It is of central importance to understand the size of a family relative to a measurement of its complexity known as the analytic conductor. In joint work with Brumley, the PI proved the first ever asymptotics for the size of certain "universal" families consisting of cusp forms on GL(n,F) arranged by their analytic conductor, which serves as the automorphic avatar of Schanuel's count of points in a projective space of bounded height. This work opens the door to analysis in this particularly natural family, within which other families of cusp forms may be embedded.

The project also supported numerous collaborations with graduate and undergraduate students, multiple conferences, and prolific mentoring of women in mathematics and junior researchers. The PI co-organized (with Pierce) and gave a lecture series in the international summer school aimed at advanced graduate students and young postdocs "L-Functions: Open Problems and Current Methods", held at the Hausdorff Center for Mathematics in Bonn, Germany, including over 1/3 U.S. participants. The PI also co-organized the international 33rd Automorphic Forms Worskhop at Duquesne University, an annual conference specifically committed to including and supporting junior researchers. Further, the PI co-organized the annual Philadelphia Undergraduate Mathematics Conference Series, the weekly Philadelphia Area Number Theory Seminar, the weekly Bi-College (Bryn Mawr/Haverford) Mathematics Colloquium, and the Tri-College Problem Solving Seminar.

The PI is in a tenure-track position at an all-female undergraduate institution, where he regularly mentors and supervises undergraduate researchers, including appropriately sized questions related to the principal problems in this project. Further, the PI has advised three Ph.D. theses (two in progress) and five M.A. theses, three of which leading to joint publications, completed three joint papers that included undergraduate and Ph.D. students as co-authors, and maintained a weekly graduate research seminar. The PI served as a Director's Mathematician in Residence in the Budapest Semesters in Mathematics, delivered further outreach lectures in an REU program, a math camp, and a magnet high school, and served on professional development panels in multiple Automorphic Forms Workshops, at Bryn Mawr College and Princeton University, and at BSM.
